> On Thu, Oct 16, 2008 at 05:36, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>> T=
hanks Ken and Matt. This is really good information, especially learning
>>=
 what rules of thumb you are operating by.
>> 
>> So, out of curiosity, if =
you do have the luxury of a larger population size
>> (presumably due to a =
problem with a quick fitness evaluation), where do you
>> recommend investi=
ng? More species, or larger species?
>> 
>> Is it better to have 100 specie=
s of size 30, or 10 species of size 300?
>> 
>> I am sure this too depends =
on the problem, but I would be interested in
>> hearing what people have fo=
und tends to work (or, at least, what they tend
>> to do).
>> 
>> Cheers,
>=
> Jeff Clune
>> 
>> Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University

 jclune@...

>>> From: Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...>
>>> =
Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
>>> Date: Wed, 15 O=
ct 2008 17:33:38 -0000
>>> To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com=
>
>>> Subject: [neat] Re: Population sizes
>>> 
>>> I haven't seen any expl=
icit studies on population size in NEAT
>>> specifically, but there have be=
en such studies for genetic algorithms
>>> in general. I think Kenneth De J=
ong's textbook, "Evolutionary
>>> Computation: A Unified Perspective" exami=
nes it.
>>> 
>>> However, of course as people have pointed out in NEAT it's=
 not just a
>>> question of a healthy population but of healthy species, si=
nce each
>>> species is like its own little population. In other words, the=

>>> species need enough internal diversity to drive their own
>>> explorat=
ions. My own rule of thumb has been a minimum of 15 members
>>> per species=
 (on average) to keep them healthy. I'm sure 30 is even
>>> safer.
>>> 
>>>=
 Another thing to note is that the population size you need can vary
>>> wi=
ldly by problem and it can be surprising. For pole balancing, it
>>> turns =
out that you can solve it fastest with a minuscule population of
>>> size u=
nder 20 total (that's for the whole population!). That is
>>> because small=
er populations are greedier (they concentrate resources
>>> on a small part=
 of the search space) and apparently pole balancing
>>> benefits greatly fr=
om greedy search. However, that is a specific
>>> property of pole balancin=
g and I would not expect it to carry over to
>>> more significant domains. =
Surely in some domains having a population
>>> over 1000 would lead to the =
most interesting results, if only you can
>>> afford the luxury of the adde=
d computational cost of a large population.
>>> 
>>> ken
>>> 
>>> --- In ne=
at@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:

 under 1000 they really start to worry about the

>>>>

any studies with NEAT on pop size to see what the
>>> plot of

>>>>> Subject: [neat] Re: Population sizes
>>>>> 
>>>>> I t=
ypically use around 150, but set the target species to 5 using a
>>>>> chan=
ging compatability threshold. This gives a rough specie size of
>>>>> 30. I=
 read somewhere, and I can't remember where, some article about
>>>>> Highl=
and cattle having to have a breeding population of 30 to make the
>>>>> gen=
e pool viable.
>>>>> 
>>>>> I guess its also a trade off with time also. I =
am evolving Torcs
>>>>> controllers for Julain Togelius' CIG 2008 commpetit=
ion. Each
>>>>> controller takes around 4 seconds to evaluate. If I had a p=
op of over
>>>>> 1000, it would take a long time for my poor laptop to fini=
sh each
>>> epoch.
>>>>> 
>>>>> Cheers
>>>>> 
>>>>> Matt
>>>>> 
>>>>> --- I=
n neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@> wrote:
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> Hello al=
l-
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> What population sizes to you typically use for NEAT?
>>>>=
>> 
>>>>>> We have done experiments in the Avida digital evolution platform=
 that
>>>>>> suggest that below 1,000 org drift starts to play a role. But =
a lot
>>>>> of the
>>>>>> HyperNEAT papers use pop sizes of 150 or so. My g=
uess is that the
>>>>> diversity
>>>>>> preserving measure ('speciation') a=
nd elitism help make smaller
>>>>> populations
>>>>>> effective, but I was =
wondering if anyone has looked at the effects of
>>>>>> population size in =
NEAT in an effort to provide a *rough but general*
>>>>>> suggestion as to =
how big to make the populations in NEAT.
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> 
>>=
>>>> Cheers,

an State University
